title: GitHub Workflows security hardening

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This PR adds explicit [permissions section](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#permissions) to workflows. This is a security best practice because by default workflows run with [extended set of permissions](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#permissions-for-the-github_token) (except from `on: pull_request` [from external forks](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/)). By specifying any permission explicitly all others are set to none. By using the principle of least privilege the damage a compromised workflow can do (because of an [injection](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-untrusted-input/) or compromised third party tool or action) is restricted.
It is recommended to have [most strict permissions on the top level](https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#token-permissions) and grant write permissions on [job level](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-jobs/assigning-permissions-to-jobs) case by case.

title: Update xor.js Documentation

body: Document the difference between `xor` _n_-ary implementation and linked _n_-ary specification.

title: Update xor description
body:
Hello,

I've read #4274 and understand the argument there. It makes good sense. However, the documentation still explicitly points to a page that describes behavior NOT matched by `xor`. The documentation should mention that the lodash implementation is not in accordance with the _n_-ary symmetric difference described on the Wikipedia page and is more like the `union` of each input array's `difference` outputs.

title: feat(Function): add method sync

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
**Problem:**
Let's say we have an async method `applySettings`
```
const async applySettings(delay) {
  return Promise((resolve) => {
    // do some stuff
    setTimeout(resolve, delay);
  })
}
```
When we call it multiple times from multiple places it comes with race conditions which leads to unpredictable behavior. 
```
applySettings(1000)
applySettings(100)
applySettings(500)

100
500
1000
```
- all 3 will run at the same time independently
- the order changed randomly

**Solution**

```
const applySettingsSynced = sync(applySettings);
applySettings(1000)
applySettings(100)
applySettings(500)

1000
100
500
```
- here they are all finished in the correct order one after one

Hello! @jdalton I checked existing functionality and did not find anything similar. Please have a look. Thanks.

title: Add `hasDeepEmpty` function

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I was working on my project until I needed this function to check form's empty values, so I implement this feature.

This function can help to check a form values (by using `predicate` argument) or a nested object for empty values like `null`, `undefined`, empty `string`, empty `object` or `array`.

Note that:
- This function get powered by lodash's `isEmpty` function, so leafs (last values in nested levels) checked by `isEmpty` function.
- This function doesn't return `true` (like `isEmpty`) for `numerical` and `boolean` type values in nested levels, because in my opinion a these types are not `empty` in nested levels.
- `predicate` function invoked when `hasDeepEmpty` detecting an empty value.
- `predicate` function has `value`, `key` and `parent` parameters when invoked.

title: add a `fillDeep` function

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
### Cenario
I need to fill an Array of independent elements to use in my Vue app. Using the `fill` function I don't have cloned objects and when I change the first element of the array, all gets changed too.

### Proposal
```javascript
const obj = { foo: 'bar' };
const arr = _.fillDeep(Array(2), obj);
console.log(arr[0] === arr[1]); // => false
```

### Workaround
```javascript
const obj = { foo: 'bar' };
const arr = _.map(Array(2), () => { ...obj });
console.log(arr[0] === arr[1]); // => false
```

labels.name: issue bankruptcy

body:
# Description

I felt the need for a function that can calculate the kth smallest item in an array, so in that case, you can also calculate the median of the array.
in order to do that, I used the quick select algorithm. (also known as Hoare's selection algorithm)
with this algorithm, you will get the average complexity of theta(n), with a worst case of O(n^2).

## Type of change

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

# Checklist:

- [x] My code follows the style guidelines of this project
- [x] I have performed a self-review of my code
- [x] I have commented on my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [x] My changes generate no new warnings
- [x] I have added tests that prove my feature works

title: toPath treats unclosed square brackets as valid path elements

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
When I call `toPath` with a string that contains unbalanced square brackets, for example:
```
toPath('my_obj[0[1')
```
The result is:
```
[
   'my_obj',
   '0',
   '1'
]
```

What I expect is for `toPath` to ignore such unbalanced brackets - they should be invalid and, in this case, `toPath` should simply return:
```
['my_obj[0[1']
```

title: When `debounce` or `throttle` options objects have `undefined` values, those options are unexpectedly set to non-defaults

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
## Background

`debounce` and `throttle` take optional `options` objects:

For debounce:

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/ddfd9b11a0126db2302cb70ec9973b66baec0975/lodash.js#L10278-L10282

For throttle:

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/ddfd9b11a0126db2302cb70ec9973b66baec0975/lodash.js#L10879-L10883

Notice that each of these options has sensible defaults.

## Bug

If you set these properties to `undefined` rather than leaving them out of the object, for example:

```js
{
  leading: undefined,
  maxWait: undefined,
  trailing: undefined
}
```

The options dangerously get set to unexpected values.

For debounce:

-  `leading` falls back to `false`
-  `maxWait` falls back to `0`
-  `trailing` falls back to `false`

For throttle:

-  `leading` falls back to `false`
-  `trailing` falls back to `false`

### Cause

The cause of this behavior is that the code is checking for settings using the `in` operator.  Instead of `'property' in options`, a much better check would be `options.property !== undefined`.

The buggy code is here:

Debounce:

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/ddfd9b11a0126db2302cb70ec9973b66baec0975/lodash.js#L10320-L10325

Throttle:

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/ddfd9b11a0126db2302cb70ec9973b66baec0975/lodash.js#L10904-L10907

## Expected Behavior

In JavaScript, we nearly always treat missing properties and `undefined` properties as the same thing. Even though this is not _technically_ true because an object can have a property with an `undefined` value, it's very surprising when code doesn't do this.

While explicitly calling these functions with undefined properties is probably very uncommon, it's not uncommon at all to implicitly do so. For example, if a function is wrapping `throttle` to extend its behavior, one can easily see how this could happen and cause very subtle and unexpected bugs.

### Example Use Case

This example is adapted from @k-funk's example in https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4973, where a React hook is extending `debounce`:

```js
function useDebounce(fn, delay, { leading, trailing, maxWait }): {
  // unrelated setup code
  const fnRef = useRef(fn)
  useLayoutEffect(() => fnRef.current = fn, [fn])

  return useMemo(
    //  Note the subtle bug here - leading, trailing, and maxWait could all be set incorrectly!
    () => debounce(() => fnRef.current(), delay, { leading, trailing, maxWait }),
    [leading, trailing, maxWait]
  )
)
```

## Related Issues

- https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4973 is a duplicate of this from 2 years ago. I decided to open a new issue to provide more context, include `throttle`, and bring the info up to date. I think we can close that issue in favor of this.

Potentially related:

- https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4869
- https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4782
- https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4650

title: lodash/get doesn't work properly when the data is null
[TS/JS] overSome() multiple args

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hello,

I encountered a strange behavior on TypeScript using `overSome()` and `overEvery()`.

Libs versions:

```json
"dependencies": {
    "@types/lodash": "^4.14.182",
    "lodash": "^4.17.21"
}
```

### The TypeScript part of the problem

It seems that TypeScript allows the function returned when calling `overSome()` to take multiple parameters:

```typescript
import overSome from 'lodash/overSome';

var testSome = overSome<string>([str => str === 'a', str => str === 'b']);
testSome('a', 'b'); // Multiple params and no TS error...
```


TypeScript tells me that the type of `testSome` is the following:

```
(local var) testSome: (...args: string[]) => boolean
```

Which seems to contradict the [documentation][documentation], and my tests (the 2nd, 3rd... args are not taken into account).


Do you agree with this? Or did I miss something?

Thank you

[documentation]: https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#overSome

title: Add Latin Extended-B and Latin Extended Additional to deburr

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This PR adds support for the Latin Extended-B and Latin Extended Additional Unicode blocks. Currently, the deburr function is missing support for a lot of commonly used characters. This means that, for example, in Romanian, the word "crat" will be deburred into "caarat". This behavior is inconsistent and confusing to the user.

This problem is not limited to Romanian  I saw multiple requests [^0][^1][^2][^3] for characters in various blocks, and so I think the community would welcome this addition.

Because not all characters have Latin equivalents, I have attached lists of the characters I did not include, from both the Latin Extended-B [^4] and Latin Extended Additional [^5] blocks. The characters I selected for deburring either have clear diacritics which can be "removed", or otherwise have a very clear equivalent Latin character.

Please note that I was not able to sign the CLA, as the [linked CLA page](https://cla.js.foundation/lodash/lodash) states "There is no CLA to sign for lodash/lodash", with an error about authorization tokens.

[^0]: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/5251
[^1]: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4530
[^2]: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3836
[^3]: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/5363
[^4]: https://paste.sr.ht/~alexandru_miricioiu/9c9cb0db922afeeee88a026ff73ea36f324fa068
[^5]: https://paste.sr.ht/~alexandru_miricioiu/9e3ef083a10ba48fd0e2c402bb96113750891fca

title: "Named Export 'last' not found" With Latest lodash-es (v4.17.21)
[Question] Any updates on version 5?
body:
Hello!

Please allow me to use this moment to say that I absolutely love `lodash` and use it in practically all my JS projects!  

I read a while ago in [this tweet](https://twitter.com/jdalton/status/1482210925511774208?s=20&t=915KudC7ZQ03Ngv4QiN4FQ) by John-David Dalton that there was some hope to release lodash 5 sometime this late spring. But it's already late July, so I've been wondering: **have there been any updates on lodash 5?** How's it going in general (if it's not a secret)?  

I haven't found any tweets / articles / github issues on this topic, so I figured the only thing I could do was to just ask  Apologies if this sounds a bit pushy. I'm just very excited, and I'm sure many others like me have been waiting for a v5 release for a long time 

Also, is there anything like a lodash blog or something that I could follow for future updates, perhaps?

Thank you for your time!

title: Remapping Numeric Values

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
# Introduction
The remap function takes in five parameters: `value`, `fromLow`, `fromHigh`, `toLow`, and `toHigh`. 
The purpose of this function is to remap a number from one range to another. 

The remap function is used in cases where we need to change a numerical value from one range to another. For example, in graphic and audio programs, this function is used to scale and adjust the volume of audio files and images. Additionally, in programs that work with various sensors such as temperature, humidity, and pressure sensors, this function is used to convert the values read from the sensors into understandable and usable values for the program.

### Syntax
```js
remap(value, fromLow, fromHigh, toLow, toHigh)
```

Here is how each parameter is defined:
- `value`: This is the number that we want to remap.
- `fromLow`: This is the lower bound of the value's current range.
- `fromHigh`: This is the upper bound of the value's current range.
- `toLow`: This is the lower bound of the value's target range.
- `toHigh`: This is the upper bound of the value's target range.

The function will return the remapped value.

### Example 

Here is an example of how to use the remap function:

```js
const remappedValue = _.remap(50, 0, 100, 0, 10);
console.log(remappedValue); // Output: 5

// OR
const useRemap = _.createRemap(0, 100, 0, 10);
console.log(useRemap(50)); // Output: 5
```

In this example, we are remapping the value 50 from its current range of 0-100 to a target range of 0-10. The expected output is 5 because 50 is exactly halfway between the current range's bounds, and so it should be mapped to exactly halfway between the target range's bounds.

title: Allow use of lodash in deno with typescript interfaces

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
There doesn't appear to be any feasible way to use lodash in deno and get typescript interfaces. As a result, lots of functionality is broken.

For example, the compiler won't recognize that a variable that returned `false` on an `isNil` check is known to not be `null` or `undefined`. This causes constant "object is possibly undefined" compiler errors.

One might expect this to work:
```typescript
// @deno-types="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/master/types/lodash-es/isNil.d.ts"
import isNil from 'https://deno.land/x/lodash@4.17.15-es/isNil.js';
```

But unfortunately, Deno can't deal with the way imports are done in those type interface files.

All of the solutions I've found either no longer work or involve using an alternative library instead of lodash.

title: new array, boolean, and combinator function requests

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I got a few wishes for some functions to be added to Lodash

# array functions
In addition to `_.every` and `_.some` it would be nice to have a `_.none`, which returns true if all inputs are falsy.
It just saves having to write `!_.some(arr)`.
It's a really minor thing, but I feel it helps when just reading the code: "**if none** of the items in **arr** are true, **then**..." instead of "**if not some** items..."

# logical functions
I noticed that `_.add`, `_.multiply`, `_.subtract`, and `_.divide` exist in Lodash, which are all nice when doing reduce operations.
Logically, it then stands to reason that the logical operators should exist as well for the same reason:
```js
const and => (a, b) => a && b;
const or => (a, b) => a || b;
const not => (a) => !a;
```
Maybe take a page out of Lisp's book, and allow for variable args, returning the last evaluated expression similar to what an `&&` or `||` chain would do.

# combinator functions
I find myself writing many of the same patterns, and many of the most common ones have combinators.

Stuff like the psi combinator (called `on` in Haskell, which takes a binary function and a unary function, and applies the unary function to both inputs before passing it along to the binary ones.

Example:
```js
const lowerEqual = _.on(_.eq, _.lowerCase); // same as (a, b) => _.eq(_.lowerCase(a), _.lowerCase(b))

console.log(lowerEqual('Foo', 'FOO')); // true
```

Or the phi combinator (also known as fork), which takes a binary and two unary functions, and applies all three to a single input:
```js
// calculates the average by dividing the sum of the array by the number of elements in it
const avg = _.fork(_.divide, _.sum, _.size, [1, 2, 3, 4]);
console.log(avg); // 2.5
```

I've included a handful that I've hand-crafted in the gist here: [[link](https://gist.github.com/ElectricCoffee/895e78355730fd88ab6671e5c20b6eea)]. The gist also includes a number of partially applied variants suffixed with `_`

title: fix: fix duplicate uniqueId generation (#5457)

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Please see #5457: The _.uniqueId function could generate duplicates.

### Summary
When the `prefix` param ends with a numeric digit, `_.uniqueId` function could previously generate duplicate IDs. This PR introduces a fix, and two new test cases. The fixed `_.uniqueId` function passes all tests (new and old). Prior to the fix, the function didn't pass the newly added tests.

### Approach
If the prefix ends with a number, we append the `'_'` character to the prefix. That is, calling `_.uniqueId('foo1')` is equivalent to calling `_.uniqueId('foo1_')`. This way, `'foo1_1'`, `'foo1_2'` ... `'foo1_11'`, `'foo1_21'` ... `'foo1_{N}'` will all be unique. Without the appended underscore, `'foo111'` could arise as `'foo1' + '11'` or `'foo11' + '1'`. Similar, `foo121` could arise as `'foo1' + '21'` or `'foo12' + '1'`

Note that `'_'` is appended only if the supplied prefix ends with a number. So, if the prefix is `'contact_'`, like in the docs, it will remain `'contact_'`; an extra underscore won't be appended. (It won't become `'contact__'`). Similarly, if the prefix is just `contact`, no underscore will be appended. But if it is `'contact5'`, an underscore will be appended, making it equivalent to the prefix `'contact5_'`. 

This approach ensures that no matter the `prefix` supplied, the generated id is always unique. At it's core, it's pretty much unchanged. We're just handling numeber-ending prefixes a bit differently.

### Aside
Instead of relying on `'$lodash$'` as a reserved (default) prefix, this PR switches the default value to `''`. This is done in a backward compatible way, i.e. when `_.uniqueId()` is called with no argument, we continue to return a numeric string (with no prefix). And while this PR is not really related to #4357, it does address the concern therein too.

title: lodash/fp/reduce missing "key" parameter in iteratee when reducing a plain object
body:
Lodash 4.17.21

Test script comparing standard reduce vs FP reduce:
```
const reducefp = require('lodash/fp/reduce')
const reduce = require('lodash/reduce')

const obj = {
  a: 'one',
  b: 'one',
  c: 'two',
  d: 'two',
  e: 'three',
  f: 'three'
}

const test = reducefp(
  (result, value, key) => {
    console.log('reducefp', result, value, key)
    return result
  },
  {}
)
test(obj)

reduce(
  obj,
  (result, value, key) => {
    console.log('reduce', result, value, key)
    return result
  },
  {}
)
```

Output:
```
reducefp {} one undefined
reducefp {} one undefined
reducefp {} two undefined
reducefp {} two undefined
reducefp {} three undefined
reducefp {} three undefined
reduce {} one a
reduce {} one b
reduce {} two c
reduce {} two d
reduce {} three e
reduce {} three f
```

Notice how the FP version iteratee's `key` is `undefined`, while the standard version is ok.

title: The _.uniqueId function can generate duplicates.

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
The `_.uniqueId` function can produce a duplicate id when the `prefix` param is a numeric string. For example:
```js
const firstId = _.uniqueId('1') // '11'
const moreIds = _.range(15).map(() => _.uniqueId()) // '2' to '16', including '11'
moreIds.includes(firstId) // true
```

Even if `prefix` is not entirely numeric, as long as it ends with a number, I think `_.uniqueId()` could produce duplicates. But I haven't dug deep into that, yet.

In either case, I think this is a bug; and if the maintainers think so too, I'd be happy to contribute tests and fixes. Thank you!

title: lodash-es ReferenceError: baseFor is not defined
body:
- version: 4.17.21

lodash-es/_baseFor.js:16:16: ReferenceError: baseFor is not defined.

by looking into this file I could confirm that it exports an undefined variable
I guess it should export basesomething?
```js
/**
 * The base implementation of `baseForOwn` which iterates over `object`
 * properties returned by `keysFunc` and invokes `iteratee` for each property.
 * Iteratee functions may exit iteration early by explicitly returning `false`.
 *
 * @private
 * @param {Object} object The object to iterate over.
 * @param {Function} iteratee The function invoked per iteration.
 * @param {Function} keysFunc The function to get the keys of `object`.
 * @returns {Object} Returns `object`.
 */
var basesomething = createBaseFor();

export default baseFor;
```

title: Lodash's GroupBy Iterations Controlled By a Parameter and when its 1 , it Returns an Object of Objects .

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Lodash's GroupBy Works in a way that it will always return an Object that each Key has its own array , but if you want to slice it to have no longer than a specific number of elements , You cannot do that with the same performance and you ave to  Loop through an Object Keys and Loop through each key value to slice it to a number.

I have added some modefications to Groupby.js that 

**1 -** now its accepting another parameter which is "Iterations" that by default its undefined and it works as GroupBy worked before if you dont pass anything ( Tests Success )

**2-** if you pass a number , it will make sure to not push any longer than that to the Array and it's same complexity for performance

**3-** If you pass 1 as iterations , it won't return you an Object of An Array per Key  ... instead it will return you an Object that each key is also an object ( rather than an array ) .. it will be easier in UI to Access that instead of accessing the key then Point to the First element of the Array to find the value.


:))

Ranganath.

title: Add tests to hasPath & fixes #5420

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Fix #5420 which is caused by the `length` getter being called and `koa` throwing an error due to no `res` being defined. It shouldn't be expected that lodash may call the `length` getter on custom objects / classes. This PR moves the array and arguments checker to before calling `length` so in other cases it will not be called.

Also added lots of tests, since there appeared to be no tests file.

title: `lodash/fp/update` gets an unexpected `undefined` value in some cases

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
For some reason I don't understand, the `lodash/fp` version of the `update` function gives its updater callback an `undefined` when I want to update the `message` property of an `Error` object.

Weirdly enough I can `get` it (both with `lodash/fp` and `lodash`), and I get the expected value when using `lodash/update`, but not when using `lodash/fp/update`.

Here is a sandbox to reproduce the bug (see `updated_error_fp.message`):
https://codesandbox.io/s/pensive-cori-dbxqqd?file=/src/index.js
The only difference I can observe is that the `message` property of an `Error` is not enumerable..

Don't know if this is a real bug or misuse on my part, but I would like to understand what is going on.

title: perf: use `===` instead of `==` of all files.

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I've noticed that there are already some PRs that do something similar to me, but they've only committed a few files.

I checked all the files in the project and replaced all `==` with `===` and `!=` with `!==` as much as possible.

The only thing that is not modified is about the `null` value, because the value being compared may be `null`, it may be `undefined`, in general, when we use `== null` or `!= null`, We may want to check if it is `null` or `undefined`.

title: _.get accesses properties on prototype chain

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hello,

I accidentally bumped into a really weird bug which I tracked down to `_.get` method.

Seems that given a path that at the end includes the property name of something that lives on the object prototype, `get` method will return that value.
I.e.:
```
a = { b: { c: 'd' } }

_.get(a, 'b.c.link')

// ->  link() { [native code] }
```
I was able to reproduce this in my code as well as on https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15 directly in the console

This seems like a bug and maybe even a potential security hole?

Thank you
